data.title: Los Angeles Times Wins 5 Pulitzer Prizes and Wall Street Journal Wins 2
data.meta_description: Los Angeles Times wins five Pulitzer Prizes to dominate news competition; wins Pulitzer for breaking news reporting and national reporting; photographer Carolyn Cole wins for feature photography; columnist Bill Stall wins for editorial writing; Daniel Neil is first automobile critic to win Pulitzer for criticism; Wall Street Journal wins two prizes; reporters Kevin Helliker and Thomas M Burton win for explanatory reporting and Daniel Golden wins for beat reporting; Dallas Morning News photographers David Leeson and Cheryl Diaz Meyer win for breaking news photography; Washington Post reporter Anthony Shadid wins for international reporting; New York Times wins for public service; Toledo Blade reporters Michael D Sallah, Mitch Weiss and Joe Mahr win for investigative reporting; Miami Herald writer Leonard Pitts Jr wins for commentary; Steven Hahn (A Nation Under Our Feet) wins for history; Edward P Jones (The Known World) wins for fiction; Doug Wright (I Am My Own Wife) wins for drama; Anne Applebaum (Gulag: A History) wins for general nonfiction; William Taubman (Khruschev: The Man and His Era) wins for biography; Paul Moravec (Tempest Fantasy) wins for music; Franz Wright (Walking to Martha's Vineyard) wins for poetry; chart; photos (L)
data.text:
The Los Angeles Times won five Pulitzer Prizes yesterday, dominating this year's competition with writing that included editorials, automobile reviews and breaking news coverage of the wildfires that devastated Southern California last fall.

The five prizes were the second-highest number of awards won by a newspaper since the awards were first given in 1917. The New York Times won seven in 2002, mostly on the strength of its reporting of the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. Aside from that unusual year, the most Pulitzer Prizes any paper has won in a single year is three.

The New York Times won the public service award yesterday for articles by David Barstow and Lowell Bergman, detailing deaths and injuries among American workers and showing how employers broke basic safety rules with impunity. The submission was moved from the investigative reporting category, where it was a finalist, by the board that administers the awards on behalf of Columbia University.

The Wall Street Journal won two prizes: for explanatory reporting, for a series examining aneurysms, by Kevin Helliker and Thomas M. Burton; and for beat reporting, for Daniel Golden's look into admission preferences given by American colleges to the children of alumni and donors.
